project-basis: We built it base on Android Studio platform. We take advantage of the Google Calendar and Google distance matrix api.
project-challenges:
1.Enable operation of add/delete event
2.Connect it with watch, and it will send notification to the watch when the final time for leaving is approaching
3.Maybe share one's calendar events with others
project-future-plans:
1.Enable operation of add/delete event
2.Connect it with watch, and it will send notification to the watch when the final time for leaving is approaching
3.Maybe share one's calendar events with others
project-purpose: Our app is ZeroLate, means never to be late, we could help users to set a more flexible deadline for each event. After logging your google account, ZeroLate could get all your events. And you could easily chose your transportation method, walking, driving or bicycling and our app will record your chose. Then we will start tracing the user’s location at 2 hours before the start time of first event. Then ZeroLate will compute user’s departure deadline based on google map’s estimated time in their transportation choice. This deadline will be showed on the first page. And user could receive a notification at this latest departure time.
project-inspiration: Has everybody used google calendar? It could notify us our daily event and manage our daily life well. However. Have you met this kind of situation?  Like, yesterday I have a group meeting with my teammates. I almost forgot it until my google calendar sent a notification. As usual I set a 10-minutes-before notification for this event. So, when I noticed it, I only have 10 minutes to run to Sudikoff, and my home is out of town.
project-lessons-learned:
1.Enable operation of add/delete event
2.Connect it with watch, and it will send notification to the watch when the final time for leaving is approaching
3.Maybe share one's calendar events with others
project-accomplishments:
1.Enable operation of add/delete event
2.Connect it with watch, and it will send notification to the watch when the final time for leaving is approaching
3.Maybe share one's calendar events with others
project-subtitle: An android app helped to advance google calendar's notification function based on users' location! Never to be late!

project-basis: The front end is built with Vue.js and a google material template called vuetify. We rely heavily on the 0x.js library. Our front end is served by netlify who provides SSL and a CDN. Our server runs express with node.js, uses postgreSQL as a database and is hosted on Digital Ocean. We use the Cryptocompare API to get real time price updates using websockets.
project-challenges: We found it challenging to take a transaction hash and reverse engineering it to find the details about the original fill order in order to figure out whether the order was still valid and partially unfilled.  It was also challenging to open a socket to gather real-time price updates from CryptoCompare, and once we had implemented it, we realized that the prices from the socket were actually less accurate than from the standard get request for prices.
project-future-plans: Waiting for other relayers to make their order books public to increase the size of our databases and finding other venues for scraping valid orders.
project-purpose: 0xchange.me is a tool for making, taking and searching a constantly pruned database of valid 0x orders in the form of a user interface and an API. We use Sai as a stable denomination to express when an order is above or below the market average highlighting arbitrage opportunities.
project-inspiration: After creating another contract that incentivized users with an ERC20 token it became apparent that initial coin adoption can be difficult to obtain. Users are wary to buy into a coin that isn't on exchanges and exchanges aren't interested in a coin that doesn't have users. Our decentralized exchange allows fledgling and niche tokens a first opportunity of exposure and liquidity. We have our own directory of user generated tokens and our API is open for anyone to submit a valid 0x order. The goal of 0xchange.me is to provide as many order offers as possible—whether in the form of niche token ICOs, other relayers (with their fees included) or anyone interested in making a trade without transaction fees. We've explored techniques for scraping the blockchain for partially filled but still valid orders in order to offer as many options as possible. We're more of a 0x order search engine than a proper relayer, with the goal of capturing users attention by providing cheap decentralized liquidity.
project-lessons-learned: Sleep is important
project-accomplishments: We came together and launched a working product in less than 27 hours after never having met each other before.
project-subtitle: A free and open relayer in the decentralized exchange ecosystem

team.participant-bubble: My contribution was building the backend - a Node/Express.js REST API server with a PostgreSQL database storing tokens and orders from the 0x protocol. I deployed the server on to a DigitalOcean Droplet.

project-basis: javascript, jquery, html, css, nodejs, 0x protocol, aqueduct, web3js
project-challenges: Making everything above work together.
project-future-plans: More sophisticated gaming experience, support other ERC20 tokens to bet.
project-purpose: Allow players to buy in the game directly with ETH through metamask wallet and bet with other ERC20-tokens. Currently it is using a concept with 0xJack game credit, which is same rate as ZRX token. The buy-in backend mechanism is powered by 0x protocol to trade ETH with other ERC-20 tokens to bet.
project-inspiration: Cross over of decentralized exchange and the online gaming space where people could play and trade at the same time.
project-lessons-learned: I'm happy to be able to integrate various frameworks together and understand more in-depth how to utilize the blockchain dev tools like metamask, ethereum-testrpc, calling the 0x protocol and etc.
project-accomplishments: Be able to make my imagination into reality this weekend.
project-subtitle: BlackJack gaming powered by 0x

project-basis: I used 1&1 Cloud Server's API along with node.js to create a Facebook messenger bot, hosted on Heroku (since that was really fast deployment).
project-challenges:
Getting set up wasn't too bad. The Facebook bot worked great! Until I tried integrating the API (which had wrappers for Perl, PHP, and Python...none of which I had chosen for my app). I used Postman to test my API calls, which helped a lot.
The node.js app also kept crashing on Heroku if I used promises for some reason (ugh). So getting the messages to be posted in the correct order was a pain.
When I tried displaying all of the servers on an account, I didn't realize I was dealing with a string instead of an array. So when I went to iterate over everything from i=0 to i=body.length, I crashed my Facebook, Heroku, and phone. Oh my. Bless JSON.parse().
I was debugging everything in production by deploying every little change to Heroku...
project-future-plans: Would love to get all of the API options in! (Sadly, I only got to the main functions for the server...there were so many more opportunities). Also, I wanted to try out the other functions with Facebook messenger's bots! Could've had more user inputs to alter the servers (description, performance options, etc...). And of course, natural language processing!
project-purpose: This Facebook bot allows admins of 1&1 Cloud Server accounts to spin up or delete servers from their accounts (and also show information about the servers on the account).
project-inspiration:
I've used 1&1 for a ton of domain and hosting related services for different organizations and clubs I've been a part of. Love the product and service. Never heard of 1&1 Cloud Server but it seemed like a cool product! Why not try out the API challenge (says every hackathon-goer)?
So...there were no Amazon Alexas left in the hardware lab. Crap. Can't do voice command. Oh well. Cortana? Nah. Twitter app? Nope. Chrome extension? Eh. Facebook chat bot? Yassss.
project-lessons-learned: Would love to get all of the API options in! (Sadly, I only got to the main functions for the server...there were so many more opportunities). Also, I wanted to try out the other functions with Facebook messenger's bots! Could've had more user inputs to alter the servers (description, performance options, etc...). And of course, natural language processing!
project-accomplishments: I learned so much during this time (see below) and have something that I can use on the go! (Though I wouldn't really need to manage many servers, haha).
project-subtitle: A Facebook Messenger Bot to interact with 1&1's Cloud Server

project-basis: I used Amazon Web Services, including Lamda, S3, Cloudwatch, and the Alexa Skills Kit.
project-challenges: Figuring out how to debug with the Alexa Skills Kit.
project-future-plans: Next steps are to create a more adaptive game with different levels that challenge users with harder questions as the game continues. Then, create a multi-player, turn-based game where users can compete against each other. Finally, develop user accounts to store previous game results and help players and parents identify which type of math problems the player can improve upon.
project-purpose: The app creates an endless number of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division problems to practice using the Amazon Echo. It's a great alternative to math flash cards.
project-inspiration: My kids kept asking me to quiz them with math questions.
project-lessons-learned: Developed and published my first custom skill on Amazon Alexa in less than 48 hours.
project-accomplishments: My kids can have fun learning math on a screen-less device.
project-subtitle: A fun, simple math game for kids and adults alike... without a screen!

project-basis: We developed three activities: A Google Maps Geolocator, a Weather/Temperature Info Screen, and an Outfit Suggestion Screen. We used the Weather Underground API, Google's Geolocation API, and some custom activity screens, which we developed and connected via the Android Studio software.
project-challenges: Because we are all relatively new to programming and the majority of our group are Hacker Rookies, we had some trouble working Android Studio and ran into some problems with syntax in XML. We also originally started out with a different weather API, and got a significant way through that portion of the project before realizing that the API would only allow you to access the weather once every ten minutes. Furthermore, the URL to access the weather changed frequently. We also had a few challenges with implementing a geolocation API, because of the large back-end data set that they require to operate fully on. We got around this by using a simpler version of it that could be implemented and combined with the other parts of the app within the time limit.
project-future-plans: Personalizing and expanding the wardrobe to better fit individual styles and genders. In a future version allowing user to customize their own outfit (by way of animation) and have the app check the outfit for style and against the forecast. In addition, we plan on implementing an algorithm that takes into account the material of the clothes to test against the temperature and humidity. For example, a linen or cotton or Dri-Fit top would be best for hot summer days.
project-purpose: Get ready for your daily dose of fashion inspo every morning. This app pulls the weather data for your location and recommends a trendy outfit perfect for the day.
project-inspiration: We would wake up in the morning, get ready for class, and check the weather on our phones - but then be clueless about how to translate the numerical temperature to an appropriate outfit.
project-lessons-learned: We all learned to code with Android Studio and XML, as well as using new APIs to further our project in general.
project-accomplishments: All four of us were first-time hackers, yet we turned out a functional product!
project-subtitle: Get outfit/fashion advice based on the weather!

team.participant-bubble: I worked on the weather aspect of the app, which involved both front-end and back-end development, as well as making use of the Weather Underground API.

project-basis: Built on top of Twilio, Amazon Web Services--especially the Api Gateway and Lambda functions, and a host of APIs, the bot is an interconnected mesh of software services.
project-challenges: Challenges... lots... at first designing a chatbot seemed like it would be simple: no UI, no problem! If only that were true.  I really liked the idea of pointing a camera at a beer and getting back information about what you were looking at. Triangulating this data was by far the most challenging aspect.
project-future-plans: I'd love to try it out. Get some friends to use it. Figure out the data on what people drink in what neighborhoods and make a map of that.
project-purpose: 1-657-BEER-BOT is a SMS + Camera + Web experience.
project-inspiration: I once heard that in ancient Rome people were able to wayfind by sampling the water. Apparently each well tasted slightly differently and after awhile you knew what part of town you were in by how metallic the water tasted.
project-lessons-learned: I think my next chatbot I'll approach with a UX flow in mind first. Even though there are no "pixels", I didn't give that part of the project enough thought. I looked at Eliza and some of the other chatbots, but they all seem to have a particular way of seeing the world that seemed more complicated than I needed it to bet.
project-accomplishments: Well, you know, pulling it all together. It seems to work!
project-subtitle: I'm not sitting at the bar alone. I'm txt'ing and learning about with my pal: 1-657-BEER-BOT.

Mathematical solution for the first challenge

project-basis: I created 43 keyword matched on the Personality Forge demo and also a custom plugin using their format. For Chattron I was able to just compile a Chatbot with much fewer variables based on what was readily available. The personality forge one, I ended up having it chat against other chatbots to see its learning mechanism.
project-challenges: Since it is an AI, its ability to learn happens through time. What I found interesting though is in both instances, one of the first thing the bot begin to develop was profanity, or adult themed stories. My bot started off talking about not knowing how to say anything, then defined a word, then it went downhill from there. It made me curious to learn how different AIs act.
project-future-plans: I may end up trying to see if I can build a chatbot that may be able to mine different data or integrate with predictive analysis APIs and talk about trends
project-purpose: It took nearly 3 hours to build the Personality Forge chatbot. Essentially I ended up putting different key phrases and had to "seek" a certain set of adjectives or variables in order for the bot to learn. The bot learns mainly through the keyphrases you assign but gets smarter through transcript history. The chattron bot on the other hand took much quicker to build because it has a mapping ability for its keyphrases and an already build in simple SDK.
project-inspiration: MHacks Nano is an only few days online Hackathon and I wanted to be able to get something done quick. I also like developing good AI applications but in the timeframe for this hack, that wasn't much of an option. Instead I used Personality Forge's API and also tested it against other competitors by compiling a different Chatbot. Using different Key phrases, you are able to develop something called AI Script and their API already comes in with an easy to use built in SHA 256 encryption key.
project-lessons-learned: One thing is for certain, AI shouldn't be given emotion or the ability to think for itself in regards to human behavior.
project-accomplishments: I am proud I got started on something for MHacks Nano, even though it is remarkably small, more simple, and less dev work then most of my other projects.
project-subtitle: Building two bots using paraphrases and an AI script genetator, then testing their responses

team.participant-desc: I am Andrew Kamal of AndSocialREW Gaming and Publishing as well as StartHub Messenger. I am currently a developer and startup consultant.

project-basis:
Informational Lists in three (3) categories:
Companies that want to distribute their excess food to local shelter register their information through the website
Shelters that want to receive the excess food from companies register their information through the website.
Partner companies that will rescue the food and deliver it to the local shelters register their information through the website.
Individual Volunteer that will rescue the food and deliver it to the local shelters register their information through the website
Volunteer coordinators will use these lists to connect the donating company with the closest local shelter to receive the excess food.   A Partner/Volunteer will be identified and confirmed to pick-up the food from the company and deliver it to the shelter.
project-challenges: State, County, and City rules and regulations with various timelines for distribution of different food groups;
project-purpose: The website/application partners companies that have excess food after meetings, workshops, conferences, parties, etc., to deliver the excess food to shelters for battered women, homeless, youth, etc.  The food is rescued and delivered to the local shelters through partnerships with Uber or Lyft and through individual volunteers.
project-inspiration: Seeing companies throw out good food after meetings, conferences, parties, etc. which could be given to clients residing at shelters for the homeless, for battered women, and for youth.
project-subtitle: website to locate excess food from corporate events and deliver it to the hungry.

1click DevOpsSec: 1click Secure Servers and 1click Security Testing

project-basis: We built the customer and employee applications in native Swift, and wrote our server-side logic using Node.js to manage a MongoDB instance hosted on MongoLab
project-challenges: We only had three hours, and we set ourselves an ambitious goal. Namely two fully functional (and aesthetically pleasing to boot) native iOS applications and a live backend. But we did it! The apps are far from a complete shopping solution, as they're mostly a proof of concept and the first step in the installment of a system to improve the retail experience for both consumers and businesses.
project-future-plans: To make full use of 1Code, a much more fleshed out system is needed. Our vision for a system of this type involves an adaptation of the already-present security tags to incorporate Bluetooth Low Energy beacon devices that act as long-lived, cheaply produced microlocation devices.
project-purpose: 1Code is a shopping utility application that allows users to scan barcodes as they travel around a store, adding items to their shopping cart. When ready, the customer goes to the register and instructs the app to "Checkout." The app automatically generates a unique QR code that is used as a key to store the users cart in the cloud. The cashier then uses his application to scan the QR code displayed on the customer's phone, and the entire cart with prices, barcodes and item names is pulled down from the server and is available to them.
project-inspiration: Macy's held a 3-hour mini-competition during HackGSU to build "an application (web or mobile) to improve the shopping experience." We set out to alleviate the biggest pain point when retail shopping: checking out.
project-accomplishments: We only had three hours, and we set ourselves an ambitious goal. Namely two fully functional (and aesthetically pleasing to boot) native iOS applications and a live backend. But we did it! The apps are far from a complete shopping solution, as they're mostly a proof of concept and the first step in the installment of a system to improve the retail experience for both consumers and businesses.
project-subtitle: A concept system of two iOS applications for streamlining the shopping experience

project-challenges: All retail APIs are different I had to bring all these different API formats into a single simple UX
project-future-plans: More stores more user options
project-purpose: Shows highly rated items across many stores that are a dollar or less.
project-inspiration: I love browsing dollar stores. I know that my favorite online stores sell things at low prices too, but it's really hard to find them. I wanted to find out if you could browse your favorite online stores for just items that are a dollar or less like a brick and mortar dollar store.

project-accomplishments: The simple effective design

One for One is a packaging design service which makes E-waste disposal convenient.

project-basis: We programmed an Android application which uses Android Location services to track the distance (in meters) which we then converted to miles. Each page of the application is an activity in android studio. We have activities that record distance, demonstrate the distance traveled out of whole distance goal per week and daily and we have a page for the settings of the app. We also have a payment information page which the user inputs their data for the payment when they are unable to run the distance per week or per day.
project-challenges: Some of the challenges we ran into were that the distance wasn't correctly calculating, and because it was a long it would export out values up to ten decimals. Other times, we forgot to include the line which actually receives the location of the user (we sent out a team member to run a mile twice and they had returned without any information actually uploaded). Furthermore, some issues included not importing libraries and having activites run on the same page which would cause things to overlap each other.
project-future-plans:
Monetary penalties is just one form of incentives we would like to offer our customers in the future. In having daily and weekly penalties, we have attempted to create a system that develops the habit of daily exercise. To further instill this principle, we plan to give our customers the option of locking their phones and other electronic devices (hooked up to a Google Service system) during a particular time in a day (which is decided that the beginning of the week). 
We plan to offer integration features for customers with Fitbits and other Wearable technology that will allow them to track their heart rate, pulse and speed. We would offer to incentivise these other measurements to our competitive trainees to improve or maintain their game daily.
project-purpose: When a customer signs up for our services, we require that It utilizes Android’s built in GPS services to calculate the distance that you travel. Using Java (Android Studio),  as well as Google play services it charges the user weekly if they didn't run the specified amount. We also used different activities that go on different pages to have the code run easily and be easily navigable.
project-inspiration: Even in a market as big as the productivity and fitness/health industry, in our research, we have found few apps that offer a solution for those who have trouble sticking to their goals and resolutions. In our personal experiences with time management and the chaos of our daily lives, sometimes fitness comes secondary to everything else that is going on. Fitness is evidently a major global issue indicating by the astonishing obesity rates in the country. Incentivising fitness and providing penalties for forgetting daily exercise is a perfect solution for those who are interested in sticking to their goals.
project-lessons-learned: When we first looked into how we were going to store the data we learned that Parse was shutting down its services [ :( ] so we had to look for other ways to store data and settled on using Android’s built in shared preferences. We also learned how to integrate external APIs like google play and paypal (although we didn’t end up using this).
project-accomplishments: Our sleek, user friendly platform and the applicability of this app
project-subtitle: A Fitness App that makes you stick to your goals by forcing you to pay for not exercising.
Find out how to save money by managing your income!

project-basis:
The proof of concept was done using the OpenCV libraries with python. Car detection was done using a haar cascade for cars found online. Detection worked on a sample video, after we restricted the area of detection to the lane directly ahead of the car.
Then we ported the program to Android Java, modeling it after a sample face recognition program using a haar cascade. On top of the application, we wanted to add pebble functionality. We added onto the java program to send notifications alerting about oncoming cars as well as writing a pebble app to allow the user to start and end the java program.
project-challenges: Haar cascade had problems with precision and false positives.
project-future-plans: Improve cascade file and UI.
project-purpose: It detects cars through haar cascade and a standard android camera.
project-inspiration: Our team was growing concerned with the rising accident toll of bicycle riders. In many city roads, bikes occupy the same lane as cars. However, many drivers are often not paying attention to bikes and this causes collisions. If we could alert the biker of an approaching car before the collision, we could shave crucial seconds off reaction time and potentially save lives.
project-lessons-learned: This was our first hackathon and we definitely took on a large task. We learned how to work with Pebble as well as vision technology.
project-accomplishments: Using open cv and pebble for the first time ever. This is our first hackathon for all four of us and we are proud that we made something that worked.
project-subtitle: Detection of Cars for Transportation Safety, especially for bikers

team.participant-bubble: Came up with initial idea and mechanism implementation. Worked on design features and UI.
Worked on car detection algorithm in Python
Ported from Python to Android of the car detection algorithm.

project-subtitle: Its more hardware than anything

project-basis: We used java in android SDK.
project-challenges: ...A lot...
project-purpose: It's a simple game, the user holds the left or right of the screen to navigate left and right on the road (respectively) if the user crashes into an obstacle a question appears, if they answer the question wrong, they die, if the answer right, they proceed. With only one life you strive to go as far as your knowledge or skill can possibly take you...welcome to 1life.
project-inspiration:
Create a something that's fun for the community...relates to road safety...and uses data about road accidents...?...Okeh...
Community = Lots of people
Fun = ...Fun
project-lessons-learned: Java, how AGILE programming works, and a whole lot of stuff about APIs. We also learnt that each member working separately on a piece of the program isn't the best idea, as it's easier to bounce ideas around as a group.
project-accomplishments: Before this hackathon we had not yet learnt java so, learning Java on the first day of the hackathon was a pretty proud achievement for our team.
project-subtitle: 1 Road, a few lines lines of code, nights of strife...gave birth 1life!

project-future-plans: Get news by country. Would like to support local news from countries like USA, UK, INDIA & AUSTRALIA.

project-challenges: Identifying keys components to reduce server load, optimizing the summarization.

Summarizes the latest news articles into 1 sentence.
Categorizes it. And can be searched by keyword.
project-inspiration:
While millions of news articles are published every day, I realized that relevancy and terseness was key.
Identifying that this solution could be implemented by machine learning & pattern recognition led to the birth of 1News.
Delivering news in its simplest form and fresh is what 1News aims for.

project-basis: We created this app on Android Studio. Our team was divided into three groups namely, graphics team, database and dev team.
project-challenges: We had to complete the business analysis of the idea of the client.
project-purpose: This app brings first generation unprivileged students to the scholarship sponsors. It creates profile for students. These students can apply for through app. The sponsors will be able to view these students and their profile to determine the eligibility.
project-inspiration: College application can be hard for first generation students, especially the ones who are financially challenged. Even in most progressive state like California, there are thousands of students who fail to join or graduate from a university. About 16.4% of Californians, i.e, more than 6 million people, live under poverty line. Since education is the key factor for escaping poverty, we wanted to help the unprivileged students get into college in an affordable manner.
project-lessons-learned: Completing the UX design as a process to truly understand the user's need.
project-accomplishments: Helping the client, who happens to be a first generation student(for life).
project-subtitle: Easy funding for college

project-basis:
We used a number of nlp libraries for python, and a RESTful server for the actual game.
First, we filter the sentences to strip out the citations and other un-needed characters.
Then, we eliminate the longer sentences, that would be very difficult to parse.
After, we pre-process every sentence, using a hidden-markov-model algorithm to tag the parts of 
speech for every word. Breaking the sentence by noun phrases, verb phrases and prepositional noun phrases gives 
us a possibility to crudely generate a question
project-challenges:
This subject is not too well documented, as there are only a few attempts at this, and even those made by
PhD students for their dissertation. We also encountered several library bugs and dependency problems.
project-future-plans:
Improve the question generation algorithm, and we also plan to implement a classifier to
rank the generated questions by their syntactic structure.
If we had more time, we'd have implemented an algorithm to check the grammar and correct any mistakes.
project-purpose: It basically scraps a given wikipedia topic and tries to generate multiple-choice questions from them.
project-inspiration: Playing quiz-up got really boring, because we were limited to predefined topics. What if we could input any topic and, using the immense wikipedia knowledge base, the game would automatically generate questions?
project-lessons-learned: A lot more than we expected
project-accomplishments: We learned a great amount of things about nlp and we improved our experience with python and javascript
project-subtitle: Compete in automatically generated quizzes
